newsitem.title: BAHRAIN: Saudi plans to offer some SABIC shares.
newsitem.headline: Saudi plans to offer some SABIC shares.

text.p: Saudi Arabia is considering plans to offer 30 percent of the state holdings in the industrial giant Saudi Basic Industries Corp (SABIC) to the public, SABIC officials said on Tuesday.

They quoted Saudi Industry and Electricity Minister Hashem bin Abdullah Hashem Yamani as saying "a ministerial committee is studying a plan to offer part of the government's holdings in SABIC to the public."
Yamani, who is also chairman of SABIC, was speaking after a SABIC shareholders' meeting in the Saudi capital Riyadh on Sunday, one official told Reuters by telephone from Riyadh.

Yamani said the offering, if it goes ahead, could reach 30 percent of a 70 percent stake the government currently holds in SABIC. Thirty percent of SABIC's shares are already traded on the Saudi stock market.
Oil-rich Saudi Arabia is actively reviewing privatisation options to reduce the state's dominant role in the economy and raise revenues after more than a decade of big budget deficits.
Shareholders of SABIC on Sunday approved a 2.5 billion riyal ($666.7 million) dividend for 1996.
SABIC, which accounts for around five percent of the world's petrochemical production, posted a net profit of 4.412 billion riyals in 1996, down from 6.281 billion riyals in 1995.
It controls and operates 16 complexes with Western and Japanese companies, producing mainly petrochemicals, plastics, fertilisers and steel.
